text:
Something like that added:

"To deactivate a Require defined in a higher level directory (to open up a
subdirectory of a protected tree) you can use the Satisfy directive, setting it
to 'Any' and allowing access with Allow and Deny options, like:
  <Directory />
   ...
   Require valid-user
   ...
  </Directory>
  <Directory /home/user/unprotected>
   Satisfy Any
   Order deny,allow
   Allow from all
  </Directory>
"

took me 10+ minutes + the irc to figure out.
creator: grin@grin.hu
slive@apache.org
text:
It's deliberately not documented because it's not really a feature, but rather a
side effect of how host and user-based access control work.  And it can be
dangerous if you don't understand the effect it will have on mod_access.  The
feature you want is a "Require off" or some such thing that really turns off
basic auth without affecting mod_access.  It doesn't currently exist (and, in
general, many config directives don't support being turned off in sub-contexts).

But I'll leave this bug open because I think that not documenting something
because it could be dangerous is probably a mistake.  Probably better to
document it and highlight the dangers.

creator: slive@apache.org
